Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)

I played around with jr some and I think overall this is looking good.  I noticed that some node-* repos are included in the blessed list, but not others.  My thinking is that we would want to include all of the ones are a transitive dep of trition service, or something else in the list?  (I would need to write a script before we could actually figure that out).  Does that match your thinking, or was there another criteria for including the node-* libraries you were using?

After playing with it, I had two comments on the formatting:
 * Would excludedRepositories be better as just a list of strings? I can't think of any key other than name we would want here.
 * Regarding the layout of repositories, my experience has been that when I use a pattern like [{name:foo}], I usually regret it and wish I had done {foo:{}}. Particularly when the names must be unique.   Was this a purposeful choice, or has your experience led you in the opposite direction?

Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)

>  I noticed that some node-* repos are included in the blessed list, but not others. 
,
I had a personal note to follow up to discuss this. My note is:

"- revisit what node-* modules should be included, e.g. useful to work with
  *our* node-* modules that use our tooling, like eslint plugin, et al.
  In triton/repos.json I've excluded a number of them.
  Should bias to *including* rather than *excluding*.
"

I'd kinda like to get this in and then circle back with a new ticket for those. Seem okay?


> * Would excludedRepositories be better as just a list of strings? I can't
>   think of any key other than name we would want here.

I don't care that strongly. We could do that and switch later if necessary.
I agree I can't think of other fields we'd want there.


> my experience has been that when I use a pattern like [{name:foo}], I usually
> regret it and wish I had done {foo:{}}.

Interesting. My experience has tended to be the other way. True that if the
common operation is to lookup by name, then the mapping can help. However,
I think the more common op here is to process an array of repo objects matching
various criteria (not just lookup by name).

I also like that this explicitly names the name field `name`, rather than
code using a `{foo: {}, bar: {}}` object calling it variously: name, short_name,
key, id, etc.

I'd like to start with it as is, if that is okay.

Patch Set 7:

> Would excludedRepositories be better as just a list of strings? 

Done this now. I also have starter repos.json's for Triton private, Manta public and SmartOS public at https://github.com/joyent/triton-dev/tree/master

I'm using this config:

```
JR_MANIFESTS=/Users/trentm/joy/triton/repos.json,~/joy/triton-dev/repos.json,~/joy/triton-dev/repos-manta.json,~/joy/triton-dev/repos-smartos.json
```

Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1 Integration-Approval+1

Going as is sounds good to me.  Excited to see this land.
Uploaded patch set 8: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Trent Mick
What does "vm" signify?

I hadn't yet put it as a "blessed" label in the README.md. I was thinking it would identify the subset of "tritonservice"-labelled repos that produce VM images, as opposed to agent services (or other release bits like the cn-tools tarball or platform).
On the multi-manifest question front, what makes this triton and not manta or something else?
I think it would be a repo defined in manta.git's "repos.json" as well.

In a multi-manifest world I had not considered what it would mean for the same repo to be defined twice.  I admin that might capture some of the messyness of the organization, but I don't know which definition a tool should believe.

My "vision" was a `jr ...` configured with both manifests. It would merge the labels from both... and for starters at least it would error out if there were competing labels, so that there shouldn't be ambiguity.
Now that we can 'archive' on github, I don't recall a motivating use case for "state".

I guess then for maintenance (see the comment below), we could have that `jr ...` maintenance command skip archived repos?  Yah, that'd be good.  If we think that sounds right, then I can remove this entry and drop support for "state" from here and the `jr` tool.
Scratch space?

This was going to be working space for the maintenance process for this file. I'd like a `jr ...` command that would support working through all new public repos from the "joyent" GitHub org and decide if it should be added to "repositories" or "notRepositories". Then after running that, one can know that repos.json is up to date.

So if someone were able to do that it would be fantastic, but I'm not sure that's feasible (at least not for me) given the hundreds of half-used, promotional, or producty-y repositories.  My expectation was that we would have to define "is it up to date?" in terms of "are there any repositories that are a transitive dependency but not included?"

I'm considering giving it a try.
I don't know if we end up with bikeshedding on whether a given Triton-ish-related promotional repo belongs in this repos.json. I guess we'd have to try to be clear and focused on the scope of repos for this repos.json.... "engineering repos related to building triton" ?

In the end, nothing is going to be perfect.  I was thinking *I'd* be able to do this maintenance.  Getting the set of transitive deps might be pretty hard too: mapping included node_modules to joyent GH repos wouold be a bit of a slog.
nit: Is "releaserepo" preerable to "release"?
fair
Done
Meta:true?

Yah, that sounds reasonable. There *is* some setup code in triton.git FWIW: https://github.com/joyent/triton/tree/master/tools

but not enough to keep this from being "meta"
Done
